climbs.name: Silver Star Glacier
climbs.fa: Fred Beckey, Joe Heib, Herb Staley and Don Wilde. May 1952

content.description: This is a great route, and is reasonable to do in a day if you have a good fitness level.  From Burgandy Col, drop down the steep snow onto the glacier and head East.  Eventually, you will arrive at the rock that leads to the summit.  Scramble up and be proud.  To descend, reverse the route.
content.protection: Most climbers will only need standard glacier gear, but some may want a light(!) rock rack for the scrambling to the summit.
content.location:
There are two starts to this climb:

Burgundy Col

The most common approach begins at mile marker 166 on Highway 20.  Drop down the embankment and cross the creek on a log, then pick up the well-defined climber's trail.  From here, make the long hike towards Burgundy Col.  Eventually, you will see a gully that heads to the Col - stay on the left of the gully and haul yourself up there.  Once at Burgundy Col, grab some water and a snack while taking in the incredible views. This approach involves about 3500 feet of elevation gain to reach Burgundy Col, where you will downclimb steep snow to gain the glacier.

Silver Star Creek

I have not personally done this approach.  There is good beta available on Summitpost and other websites, but you essentially stay on the East side of the mountain the whole time and avoid the climb to Burgundy Col. This is the best option when it is early season and there is plenty of snow covering the approach.

content.description:
This often overlooked but stunning ridge follows a continuous path from the Cedar Creek TH to the summit of Silverstar.

Geof and Larry graded it 5.8 IV, soloing the entire ridge and skirting some of the sub summits. If you rope up earlier or keep a continuous path up the ridge it can easily become 5.9+ V or harder.

I gave it an PG13 rating due to the loose rock encountered on route, and another parties agreement that it was quite dangerous. I would say PG13/R is fair depending on your chosen route.

The best beta I can provide is to try and follow the ridge as much as possible. Just follow your intuition and enjoy the flow.

If you think you need more specific beta, this is likely not the route for you.

Some history for the route can be found in this NWMJ article

Part 1

and

Part 2

The Wa Pass Traverse TR

My TR with photos for stoke
content.protection: Standard rack. You can easily bring more or less depending on comfort level and intended route. Lots of spare cord is recommended to back up rappel anchors.
content.location: Approach from the Cedar Creek Trailhead. Turn right up the old Horse packers trail (shown on FS maps) a few hundred feet up the trail. Follow the ridge the rest of the way.

pathTokens: Hwy 20 and North Cascades National Park
